publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

history.provenance: found in Murtuqduring T III M 137

seg.seg: Why are they no appearance? Therefore it is not connected ...
To leave the appearance caused by the rebirth in the bad existences - [that is the good] appearance (?)

p.note: This fragment was identified by Schmidt (473) as 6.22-23 of Vasubandhu's Abhidharmakośabhāṣya (347-8). As a result, recto and verso had to be reversed compared to 104-5 (see 223), and several improvements in the reading have been made possible. On this passage, see : vol. IV, p. 173-7.
glosses Skt. Abhidh-k-bh (347 l. 23) (ūṣ)[m](a)gatalābhī 'who obtains heat'. The gloss is probably not complete and may not be Tocharian.

glosses Skt. Abhidh-k-bh (348 l. 3) kuśalamūlā(ni) 'the roots of merit'. It is not certain that this gloss is actually in Tocharian B: it could also be a note in Sanskrit. The preceding gloss vṛ for vṛtti under parihīṇo 'lost' indicates that the commentary begins (474).
ketsi must stand for kāttsi, introducing probably a following explanation; see line below.
glosses Skt. Abhidh-k-bh (348 l. 6) apāyān yāti 'goes to bad existences'.

The spelling ṣ ma as one akṣara for expected ṣ\ mā is highly peculiar, should this be the correct reading. The word veṣ also occurs in the gloss to the next line and may be a borrowing from Skt. veṣa (a.o.) 'appearance'. mäskeṃntar has a for ä in the final syllable.
comments on Skt. Abhidh-k-bh (348 i. 14) (apāyānāṃ kila v)y[āv]ṛ(ttatvāt) 'because of the destruction of the bad existences'.
The restoration of the gloss is of course uncertain: only the abstract suffix -lñe is preserved.

As for the rest of the line, ṣaräm is a late form of ṣarm (57). Similarly, the interpretation of laṃsi as 'leave' takes it to be a late form of lantsi. The following Sanskrit gloss [p]ṛthagjina syāt\• must stand for [p]ṛthagjanaḥ syāt\•, probably to be understood as a continuation of the Tocharian part, i.e. '[otherwise] he may become a [p]ṛthagjana (ordinary man)'. Under the akṣara vi of the following vivartya in the same line, an indication vṛ for vṛtti is found, indicating the beginning of the commentary (see 474).
The longer phrase comments on Skt. Abhidh-k-bh (348 l. 16) trīṇy api itara '[One may remove] three [nirvedhabhāgīyas] and [become] another [Buddha]' (cf. : vol. IV, 175-6).

kāttsi obviously marks different sections in the Sanskrit text, apparently a following explanation. The element ve is unclear. Perhaps it is an abbreviation of the word veṣ, found in the glosses to the lines above? A similar gloss is found on the recto, line ketsi ve above.
glosses Skt. yāsmāt (for yasmāt, not in Abhidh-k-bh (348 l. 19), as noted by 474) 'because'.

list.item: a1x /// ... a2x good a3x why? b1x Why are they no appearance? Therefore it is not connected ... b2x non-existence (?) b2y To leave the appearance caused by the rebirth in the bad existences - [that is the good] appearance (?) b3x why?
a1x /// jaṃ a2x ku(śala)- /// a3x ketsi ve b1x – – k· y· kā veṣ ma mäskeṃntar t_usa mā ritteträ te m· y· b2x /// (mā-nesa)lñe b2y apāyntane cmelñeṣṣe ṣaräm veṣ laṃsi veṣ b3x kāttsi ve
There are more possible glosses visible: (1) under the beginning of a2, (2) under the end of b4. Please check. –Martin (Tue, 2018-10-09, 14:53:53 (CEST))

This fragment was identified by Schmidt ([[Schmidt KT 1990]]: 473) as 6.22-23 of Vasubandhu's Abhidharmakośabhāṣya ([[Pradhan 1975]]: 347-8). As a result, recto and verso had to be reversed compared to [[SHT V]]: 104-5 (see [[SHT VI]]: 223), and several improvements in the reading have been made possible. On this passage, see [[La Vallée Poussin 1980]]: vol. IV, p. 173-7.

a1x glosses Skt. Abhidh-k-bh ([[Pradhan 1975]]: 347 l. 23) (ūṣ)[m](a)gatalābhī 'who obtains heat'. The gloss is probably not complete and may not be Tocharian.

a2x glosses Skt. Abhidh-k-bh ([[Pradhan 1975]]: 348 l. 3) kuśalamūlā(ni) 'the roots of merit'. It is not certain that this gloss is actually in Tocharian B: it could also be a note in Sanskrit. The preceding gloss vṛ for vṛtti under parihīṇo 'lost' indicates that the commentary begins ([[Schmidt KT 1990]]: 474).

a3x glosses Skt. Abhidh-k-bh ([[Pradhan 1975]]: 348 l. 6) apāyān yāti 'goes to bad existences'.

b1x comments on Skt. Abhidh-k-bh ([[Pradhan 1975]]: 348 i. 14) (apāyānāṃ kila v)y[āv]ṛ(ttatvāt) 'because of the destruction of the bad existences'.

b2x (mā-nesa)lñe glosses Skt. Abhidh-k-bh ([[Pradhan 1975]]: 348 l. 15) (asaṃbha)v(a)ḥ 'impossible'.

b2y The longer phrase comments on Skt. Abhidh-k-bh ([[Pradhan 1975]]: 348 l. 16) trīṇy api itara '[One may remove] three [nirvedhabhāgīyas] and [become] another [Buddha]' (cf. [[La Vallée Poussin 1980]]: vol. IV, 175-6).

b3x glosses Skt. yāsmāt (for yasmāt, not in Abhidh-k-bh ([[Pradhan 1975]]: 348 l. 19), as noted by [[Schmidt KT 1990]]: 474) 'because'.

a3x ketsi must stand for kāttsi, introducing probably a following explanation; see line b3x below.

b1x The spelling ṣ ma as one akṣara for expected ṣ\ mā is highly peculiar, should this be the correct reading. The word veṣ also occurs in the gloss to the next line and may be a borrowing from Skt. veṣa (a.o.) 'appearance'. mäskeṃntar has a for ä in the final syllable.

b2x The restoration of the gloss is of course uncertain: only the abstract suffix -lñe is preserved.

b2y As for the rest of the line, ṣaräm is a late form of ṣarm ([[Peyrot 2008]]: 57). Similarly, the interpretation of laṃsi as 'leave' takes it to be a late form of lantsi. The following Sanskrit gloss [p]ṛthagjina syāt\• must stand for [p]ṛthagjanaḥ syāt\•, probably to be understood as a continuation of the Tocharian part, i.e. '[otherwise] he may become a [p]ṛthagjana (ordinary man)'. Under the akṣara vi of the following vivartya in the same line, an indication vṛ for vṛtti is found, indicating the beginning of the commentary (see [[Schmidt KT 1990]]: 474).

b3x kāttsi obviously marks different sections in the Sanskrit text, apparently a following explanation. The element ve is unclear. Perhaps it is an abbreviation of the word veṣ, found in the glosses to the lines above? A similar gloss is found on the recto, line a3x ketsi ve above.
a1x /// jaṃ a2x ku – /// a3x ketsi ve b1x – – [k]· [y]· [k]ā ve_ṣ ma _m_askeṃnta_r\• t_usa [m]ā rittet_r_a te m· [y]· b2x /// lñe b2y apāyntane cmelñeṣṣe ṣa_r_a_m\• ve_ṣ\• laṃsi ve_ṣ\• b3x kāttsi ve

div.p: There are more possible glosses visible: (1) under the beginning of , (2) under the end of . Please check. –Martin (Tue, 2018-10-09, 14:53:53 (CEST))
